Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story:
I stared at the package in my hands, the address clear, the house silent. As a delivery person, my job was simple: make sure every parcel reached its owner, safe and sound. Today, though, the doorbell echoed into emptiness. I glanced at the porch, wondering if leaving the box there would be enough. My supervisor’s words rang in my ears—no lost packages, no excuses. I needed this job; every paycheck mattered.

But my mind kept drifting to something bigger. My savings, carefully set aside for years, were finally enough for Hajj. My friends were booking their flights, sharing plans and prayers. As a Muslim, this was my chance, maybe my only one, to fulfill a lifelong obligation. But what if something happened to the package? If I lost my job, the money for Hajj would vanish with it. I felt torn, the weight of two worlds pressing on my chest—one demanding duty to my work, the other calling me to my faith. I stood on the porch, package in hand, heart pounding, caught between what I must do and what I longed to do.
